events.name: Cybersecurity for Startups: The Case for Security
events.description:
A discussion on cyber security in start-ups. Why it is important to establish a start-up with security in mind from the beginning, what the cost is of adding it in later, the dangers of stolen IP, and how to navigate creating a secure start-up while not losing the start-up feel.

Registration starts 6.30pm. Ticket includes 1 free drink.

Panelists: 
Jamie Rubbi-Clarke from Control Risks
Eric Meyer from Apvera
Christopher Aw from MarkLogic

Lawrence Wong from PwC will be moderating this event.

Bio:
Jamie Rubbi-Clarke is Associate Director of Cyber Risk Consulting APAC at Control Risks, a global risk management firm specializing in political, security, and integrity risks. Previously, Jamie worked for the UK Foreign Office on intelligence strategy, and has consulted for some of the world’s most secure organizations, as well as working at a cybersecurity startup in the UK.

Eric Meyer currently heads Apvera, a threat intelligence platform that enables organizations to identify anomalies in user context aware behaviour. He is currently server of the board of the Open Information Security Foundation. His passion for emerging technologies and innovation has given him over 20 years of global experience in operational strategy, scaling technology businesses, company-wide transformation, serial entrepreneurship, and raising capital. He previously held senior leadership positions at Microsoft, EMC, and Infosys, as well as founded Nubefy and Optynex Telecom.

Christopher Aw is a former US Air Force officer focused on tactical communication, E&I, senior-staff roles, R&D, HUMINT, SIGINT, and all-source intelligence. In addition to the military, Chris served as a consultant, providing technology recommendations ranging from RF communications and computer networks to electro optical, infrared, hyper spectral imagery, LIDAR, and other sensor modalities. Chris has also helped author numerous US government policies regarding technology in support of military and intelligence operations. Chris is a partner at Kinkayo, a cyber threat intelligence firm focused on the Dark Web and also serves as a director at Aves Netsec, a virtualized honeypot technology provider. Additionally, Chris consults for other cyber security firms entering new markets with a focus on cyber threat intelligence.

Moderator:
Lawrence Wong is Deputy Head of Government and Public Services at PwC Singapore, where he drives government sector initiatives and serves as the firm’s industry expert on public policies. He also plays a key role in establishing and strengthening relationships with key government agencies, and in delivering projects and thought leadership on economic policies and innovation. Previously, Lawrence was Strategist / Senior Assistant Director at the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

events.name: Singapore SharePoint Community Meeting - November 2016
events.description: Hi All, SharePoint Online - CSOM Programming Tools and Tricks Senthamil Selvan, Windows App Dev MVP In this session, we will run through CSOM API and the tools used to execute script for SharePoint Online. We will share a code sample for automation of file migration, report generation and day-to-day administration activities. CSOM makes it easy to automate most of the administrative activities for SharePoint Online.
events.location: Microsoft Singapore, One Marina Boulevard, Level 22, Meeting Room

events.name: Docker + Drupal 8: Spin-up local environment in fast and easy way
events.description:
It's all microservices nowadays man!! :) OK, enough of the jargon. Before we get into that, I would like to introduce with this beast called Docker.  For those of you who doesn't know yet about what Docker is, it is a container-based open platform for developing, shipping and running applications. Sounds simple right? But what's the benefits of it?  Besides some that were mentioned here, here, here and here, based on my knowledge and personal experienced: • Can be a replacement for Vagrant :)• Easy and fast way to spin-up any services you'd like, ie: Redis, ElasticSearch, Consul, you name it!• Isolated separate environment without interrupting other services. So on this meetup I will share with you about what Docker is actually about, how to create a basic Docker configuration, and integrate it with Drupal 8 so you can happily develop cool stuff with Drupal 8 in your local machine, fast and easy way. And perhaps we can discuss some other things too along the way. Sounds cool?! :) If it is, then please RSVP to mark your attendance, and I'll look forward seeing you all in 22 Nov. Cheers!  Ardi Note:We're not going to provide food or drinks this time since organizing it (and cleaning up afterwards) is time-consuming and seems to be one of the reasons we got tired of planning the meetups. So, we'll keep it simple and just focused on Drupal. But, feel free to bring snacks and drinks for yourself and for sharing! As always, we'll convene downstairs at the food court for dinner, drinks and conversations after the meetup. 



About Presenter / Facilitator:Pratomo Ardianto (Ardi) Ardi is senior web developer working at X-Team. He has years of experience working with Drupal, developing websites for start-up companies to corporates. Ardi is also very active in Drupal Community, and been giving few talks in Drupal Meetups and Drupal Camp Singapore.

events.name: Generics in Java and Scala
events.description: This time Lim will give an introductory talk that will explore the power of Generics to write simpler, safer, more flexible code. Here it is ...   Functions in dynamically typed languages, like JavaScript, accept inputs without types. This provides convenience but it is the developers responsibilities to provide the right input types to the functions during run-time. If the developers fail to do so, the program will most likely to crash and halt. On the other hand, statically typed languages like Java, check the types during compilation and fails when the input variables do not match the function parameters' type. Catching type errors early is good but it makes the functions rigid because the functions only accept the type (and its subclasses) defined in the parameters.  Generics or better known as parametric types in Scala provides the flexibility for functions to accept different input types safely i.e. type-safety. It provides information to the compiler to catch types errors during compilation. This will also reduce type related unit tests. The downsize to this is the complexities that come with the language syntax and behavior. This is just one of the many uses of generics.   Some of the take-home for this session are: - 1. A starting point to write simple and type-safe functions.   2. Reduce in runtime exceptions as a result of less class casting.  3. Understand some of the "cryptic" methods in Javadoc or Scaladoc e.g., def foldLeft[B](z: B)(op: (B, A) -> B): B  About the speaker: A recovering Java developer who has keen interest in Functional Languages after knowing the good practice advocated by these languages.
events.location: ThoughtWorks office, 87B Amoy Street, Level 3, Singapore
